p.s: The scene of the given excerpt from William Shakespeare's comedy The Merchant of Venice takes place on a street in Venice where Shylock meets Tubal, a Jewish friend of his, and they start talking about Shylock's daughter and his bond with Antonio.

The scene is part of the rising action of this play for it follows the exhibition which includes the introduction of the character but is still happening before Shylock's and Antonio's case goes to court.
Shortly before, Jessica, Shylock's daughter, ran away with a Christian man and took money and jewelry of her father with her.
Now, Shylock encounters Tubal and asks him hopefully whether he was able to find his daughter.
As Tubal has to answer this question in the negative Shylock finds himself in misery and starts ranting about his daughter's misbehaviour and his sadness about her actions.
Tubal tries to lift him up by telling him that Antonio is miserable as well because his ships are said of to have been cast away.
For Shylock these are good news and he delights in his hope to finally get revenge for all the bad things tha have happened to him.

Still, his daughter took a lot of money from him and even a ring that Shylock's dead wife had given to him which puts him into an interior conflict between grief about Jessica and enthusiasm about Antonio.
The conversation between Shylock and Tubal ends with their hope for justice for Shylock as they both leave the scenery.
